div.p: FEELING that one's SELF:own SITUATION IS INTENSELY BAD.

1. The most representative current general word for distress is probably kùn 困 (ant. ān 安 "be in a good state"), although the group of words discussed here is selected on singularly problematic grounds.
2. Qióng 窮 (ant. tōng 通 "have a way out from a difficult situation") refers to a form form of distress as something from which it is impossible or hard to escape.
3. Kǔ 苦 and the much rarer xīn 辛 (ant. lè 樂 "be in a joyful state") refer to a lasting objective state of distress caused by identifiable external conditions.
4. Shāng 傷 (ant. yuè 悅 ) refers to lasting psychological distress.
5. Yōu 憂 (ant. xǐ 喜 "joyful occasion") may very occasionally be used to refer not as standardly to worries of some kind, but to an objective state of precarious trouble.
6. Jiù 疚 refers to purely psychological and often moral distress caused by a bad conscience or the like.

rough draft to BEGIN TO identify synonym group members for analysis, based on CL etc. 18.11.2003. CH ／

GREEK KEYWORDS
άγανακτέω contr.vb. 1 feel annoyance or resentment, be
aggrieved or distressed (sts. w.dat. or prep.phr. at events,
circumstances, another’s actions or words) Th. Ar. Att.orats.
PL + —W.ACC. in one’s guts Ar.
2 (of a soul sprouting wings) feel discomfort, ache PL

bibl.title: Anthologia sive Florilegium rerum et materiarum selectarum

entry.def: Shāng 傷 (ant. yuè 悅) refers to lasting psychological distress.

sense.def: feel distressed; feel so very distressed
be designed to cause mental distress or excessive feelings of sadness
feel distress about the contextually determinate object

entry.def: The most representative current general word for distress is probably kùn 困 (ant. ān 安 "be in a good state"), although the group of words discussed here is selected on singularly problematic grounds.

sense.def: be distressed; feel distressed; be in desperate state; be in straights;
get into trouble, have a hard time 大困
occasionally causative vt: cause trouble for, make life difficult for
be troubled by; be distressed; be reduced to trouble
be distressed with N, be in trouble with respect to N
be in trouble regarding Nab; be in distress because of Nab
crisis point; momentary crisis; momentary state of distress
be grieved; distressed in mind; sad; sorrowful

entry.def: Yōu 憂 (ant. xǐ 喜 "joyful occasion") may very occasionally be used to refer not as standardly to worries of some kind, but to an objective state of precarious trouble.

sense.def: be in deep trouble (of a state or a person)

entry.def: Jiù 疚 refers to purely psychological and often moral distress caused by a bad conscience or the like.

sense.def: cause distress; cause a person/oneself to be distressed
be in trouble; be in a precarious situation; be hard pressed; be in straights[or vtpass ??]
be in severe trouble with regard to V-ing

entry.def: Qióng 窮 (ant. tōng 通 "have a way out from a difficult situation") refers to a form form of distress as something from which it is impossible or hard to escape.

sense.def: have come to a dead end; be in a hopeless position; be in an intellectually hopeless position, be lost for words; be at one's wit's end
run into trouble, get into a tight corner
drive to exhaustion, wear out completely; put in a tight spot
cause to be in a hopeless position; put in a tight corner; put in an impossible position; embarrass
get (oneself) into an inescapable kind of trouble
be in great trouble; feel cornered; be in extreme distress
be in intellectual distress and at one's wit's end

entry.def: Jiān 艱 refers to hardship and diffuculties, typically with respect to certain tasks.

sense.def: archaic: be troublesome, be fraught with difficulties

entry.def: Kǔ 苦 and the much rarer xīn 辛 (ant. lè 樂 "be in a joyful state") refer to a lasting objective state of distress caused by identifiable external conditions.

sense.def: those who are in hard circumstances, those who have a hard time; those who suffer hardship
be in hard circumstances, suffer hardship; be distressful; (of tasks) be hard work; be devoid of joy 樂
be harder to bear, be more distressful than
(by litotes (see RHETORICAL DEVICES):) be unhappy; be quite dissatisfied
suffer distress so as to die > die in distress
be in trouble; get into trouble
urgent distress; current urgent distressful concerns
feel currently and urgently distressed by
be difficult, be strenuous, full of hardship be in distress
suffer distress so as to become debilitated
suffering bitter distress in the process of V-ing
be distressed, be exhausted, be tired
in a manner reminding one of heavily distressed people
inflict psychological harm to the contextually determinate N
feel distressed by the contextually determinate N
